Navigation Menu Social Media News Social Media News Social Media Help Facebook Help Twitter Help Google+ Help LinkedIn Help Instagram Help Pinterest Help Youtube Help Technology Technology News Tech Tips Apps & Software Gadgets Tablets Apple Kindle Samsung Internet Search Engine News Web Bing Google Yahoo Business Advertising Blogging Development Start Ups Mobile Android Blackberry iPhone Reviews Windows Phone Infographics Follow us on Twitter Follow us on Facebook Subscribe To Rss Feed Follow Us On Google+ Home Â» Apple became the latest member of the Wireless Power Consortium Apple became the latest member of the Wireless Power Consortium Home Â» Apple Â» Apple became the latest member of the Wireless Power Consortium Posted By Martha Papadimitriou on Feb 14, 2017 | 0 comments Share the joy Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Does this mean that Apple is going to bring wireless charging to the next iPhone? source:https://9to5mac.com/2017/02/13/apple-iphone-8-wireless-charging/ There are many rumors about the next iPhone. One of them is that Apple will feature wireless charging to their next smartphone. And this is very possible due to the fact that Apple joined the Wireless Power Consortium, a group for wireless power. According to reports the company will present a phone that will use inductive s charging and that the company will not provide a charger. But it will offer it as an extra accessory. On the other hand maybe the tech giant wants to adopt the long-range charging. And why not? According to a survey from IHS Technology showed that more than 90% of smartphone users want to have wireless charging. 9to5Mac provided a statement from Apple to Business Insider: â€œApple is an active member of many standards development organizations, as both a leader and contributor. Apple is joining the Wireless Power Consortium to be able to participate and contribute ideas to the open, collaborative development of future wireless charging standards. We look forward to working together with the WPC and its members.â€ Quick reminder that the next iPhone will probably feature an edge-to-edge display with almost invisible bezels, no Home button and a flexible plastic OLED screen. Also Apple filed an unnamed wireless device with the Federal Communications Commission. And the speculations fly around. Is it a speaker for Siri, like Alexa? Is it another smart device for your home? Maybe a Wi-Fi? But the company is super secretive about its new project. All we know is that the device exists, it has Bluetooth, LE and NFC. Keep in mind that this is not the first time that Apple filed to the FCC for a similar device. At first many thought that it was an Apple TV but that plan was quickly dismissed. According to a report from MacRumors it is possible that the California-based company manufactured a device for internal use, such as iBeacon which is used by the company to communicate with OS devices. If you want to check out the mysterious device you can visit the FCC website. And if you manage to figure out what it might be let us know in the comment section. Navigation Home News / Articles App Reviews Accessory Reviews Podcast TiP Us Join the TiP team HOT TOPICS: iPhone 8 TV app AirPods MacBook Pro with Touch Bar iPad Pro You are here: Home > Apple reportedly signed a deal with Samsung to produce 160 million OLED panels for iPhone 8 Apple reportedly signed a deal with Samsung to produce 160 million OLED panels for iPhone 8 February 13, 2017 Peter Cao Leave a comment The Korea Herald reports that Samsung has inked a deal with Apple to help produce 160 million OLED panels for the upcoming iPhone. The next generation iPhone will likely debut sometime in the fall, so Apple will need as many OLED panels as it can get for its new flagship. The iPhone 8 will be a major departure from its predecessor, featuring a 5.2-5.8-inch OLED display. Rumors suggest that the new phone will have nearly no bezels and will integrate the Home button and Touch ID sensor into the screen. Apple is expected to launch the new iPhone, dubbed iPhone 8, this fall on its usual yearly iPhone refresh cycle. However, the demand will be much higher than before as the new phone is slated to be a major departure from its predecessor, the iPhone 7. Itâ€™s expected that Samsung will be the main provider for the OLED display. LG Display reportedly will be joining to help reduce the load next year. Navigation Home News / Articles App Reviews Accessory Reviews Podcast TiP Us Join the TiP team HOT TOPICS: iPhone 8 TV app AirPods MacBook Pro with Touch Bar iPad Pro You are here: Home > Another Apple patent hints at Touch ID sensor being embedded into the iPhone display Another Apple patent hints at Touch ID sensor being embedded into the iPhone display February 14, 2017 Peter Cao Leave a comment With the rumors of a bezel-free iPhone 8, itâ€™s not too surprising to see Apple have patents for an embedded Touch ID sensor in the display. On the other hand, Apple has also been reportedly working on an iris scanner for the new iPhone, which would replace fingerprint scanners. Weâ€™ve previously seen two different methods of an embedded Touch ID sensor, and todayâ€™s patent marks a thirdâ€¦ The patent, discovered by AppleInsider, describes using infrared emitters and sensors placed along the LEDs inside an OLED display. Exemplary methods and systems use a micro light emitting diode (LED) in an active matrix display to emit light and a sensing IR diode to sense light. A display panel includes a display substrate having a display region, an array of subpixel circuits, and an array of selection devices. Each subpixel circuit includes a driving circuit to operate a corresponding infrared (IR) emitting LED in a light emission mode. Each selection device may be coupled to a corresponding sensing IR diode to operate the corresponding sensing IR diode in a light sensing mode. This method seems to only work with an OLED display, however. Which means certain models, which would feature an LCD display, would not work. Tags: 2017 iPhone, Patent, Touch ID About Peter Cao Peter has a passion for music and technology. He conceits himself by religiously rocking the Apple brand. You can find him on Twitter @iPeterCao. Navigation Menu Social Media News Social Media News Social Media Help Facebook Help Twitter Help Google+ Help LinkedIn Help Instagram Help Pinterest Help Youtube Help Technology Technology News Tech Tips Apps & Software Gadgets Tablets Apple Kindle Samsung Internet Search Engine News Web Bing Google Yahoo Business Advertising Blogging Development Start Ups Mobile Android Blackberry iPhone Reviews Windows Phone Infographics Follow us on Twitter Follow us on Facebook Subscribe To Rss Feed Follow Us On Google+ Home Â» Apple Considers Videos Vital To Its Growing Music Subscription Services Apple Considers Videos Vital To Its Growing Music Subscription Services Home Â» Apple Â» Apple Considers Videos Vital To Its Growing Music Subscription Services Posted By Jane Danes on Feb 14, 2017 | 0 comments Share the joy Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Source: https://www.engadget.com/2017/02/14/eddy-cue-reveals-planet-of-the-apps-reality-show-details/ The senior vice president of Internet Software and Services of Apple, Eddy Cue, said that videos could have a vital role in its growing music subscription services. He emphasized that by hosting more than music to its Apple Music will set the service apart from its competition. During a Recodeâ€™s Code Media conference, he said that adding video can be one of the differentiating elements that the company can add to Apple Music. In its 15 months, the service has grown to 20 million users, thereby, allowing it to be the fastest-growing subscription services. The company will add videos to its subscription service through its upcoming launch of reality TV show. One of them is the Planet of the Apps. Produced by Propagate Content, this showâ€™s main stars are app developers. What Is The Planet Of The Apps? In this show, contestants will make a pitch about their iOS apps to the judges while they descend an escalator. They must impress the panel of judges, consist of Jessica Alba, Gwyneth Paltrow, Gary Vaynerchuk and Will.i.am, to be included in the list of final developers for mentorship. During the last round, they need to pitch their app ideas to Lightspeed Venture Partners. The company has committed to more than $10 million in capital to fund the winning app. The winning app will be featured on the App Store. During the Code Media conference, the showâ€™s co-producer, who was also present during the Code Media chat, said that apps play a major role in the current cultural landscape. Eddy Cue also emphasized on the companyâ€™s strategy as an influencer of the culture. Although Apple acknowledged videoâ€™s role in its music subscription service, it is not planning to buy a lot of TV shows. Instead, it wants to do something creative that can surely move culture. Apart from the Planet of the Apps, the company will also release Carpool Karaoke: The Series. It is set to be available on Apple Music soon. It is based on the popular segment of the Late Late Show, hosted by James Corden. In this TV show, he rides with celebrities and sings in a car. Previous reports stated that Apple ordered 16 episodes that will stream weekly on Apple Music. It will be presented by Fulwell 73 and CBS Television Studios. As regards to the host, it is noted that James Corden wonâ€™t be hosting it. Cue also said that constant introduction of new services was a key to the serviceâ€™s growth. He stated that less than 100 million people in the world are subscribed to music. But Cue also emphasized that Apple Music will still be completely about music, even though those new shows will appear on Apple Music. Then again, he said that the shows of MTV were not about music. So, Apple Music will be about culture, rather than concentrating on music. He also said that it would try to add Apple News to cut down fake news. Navigation Home News / Articles App Reviews Accessory Reviews Podcast TiP Us Join the TiP team HOT TOPICS: iPhone 8 TV app AirPods MacBook Pro with Touch Bar iPad Pro You are here: Home > Apple joins Qi, a wireless charging consortium, further confirming the possibility of wireless charging in the iPhone 8 Apple joins Qi, a wireless charging consortium, further confirming the possibility of wireless charging in the iPhone 8 February 13, 2017 Peter Cao Leave a comment Itâ€™s been widely rumored that Apple will bring some form of wireless charging to the next iPhone, widely dubbed as iPhone 8. Apple is now listed as a member of Qi, a wireless charging consortium, something they werenâ€™t apart of a week ago. Early rumors suggest that Apple is working on long range wireless charging, however, that technology may not be ready at launch so the company may other manufacturers with short range charging via a pad of sorts. Similar to the current Apple Watch, the iPhone would be placed on some sort of magnetic charger, and would be a separate accessory. While Apple may want long-range RF charging, the company couldnâ€™t wait and is joining Qi as a result, according toÂ IHS Technology analyst Vicky Yussuff. The success of wireless charging adoption from Appleâ€™s competitors is something that Apple can no longer ignore. IHS Technology consumer survey data shows over 90% of consumers want wireless charging on their next device. Apple has also stepped in and provided us a statement. Apple is an active member of many standards development organizations, as both a leader and contributor. Apple is joining the Wireless Power Consortium to be able to participate and contribute ideas to the open, collaborative development of future wireless charging standards. We look forward to working together with the WPC and its members. Tags: 2017 iPhone, Qi, Wireless charging About Peter Cao Peter has a passion for music and technology. He conceits himself by religiously rocking the Apple brand. You can find him on Twitter @iPeterCao. Navigation Home News / Articles App Reviews Accessory Reviews Podcast TiP Us Join the TiP team HOT TOPICS: iPhone 8 TV app AirPods MacBook Pro with Touch Bar iPad Pro You are here: Home > Apple removes inventory for LG UltraFine 5K Display as LG continues to fix interference issues Apple removes inventory for LG UltraFine 5K Display as LG continues to fix interference issues February 13, 2017 Peter Cao Leave a comment Now that LG is aware that their LG UltraFine 5K Displays have interference issues, Apple is now removing the displays from its inventory and sending them back to LG. Appleâ€™s online store is out of stock and will begin shipping in 5-6 weeks. The display went on sale late last year with an introductory price of $974 until the end of March as part of Appleâ€™s USB-C sale. Apple said back in March during its MacBook Pro event that itâ€™s working with LG to integrate the display with macOS. The UltraFine display is Appleâ€™s current solution for those who are looking to purchase an external Retina display to replace their current Thunderbolt Display. An Apple Customer Support representative confirmed that Apple has removed the display from its store shelves with no indication of when theyâ€™re going back in stock. Appleâ€™s online store lists the display with 5-6 week ship dates with no option to pick-up in store. You might like a romantic person or an adventurous character. Or your are only want to date people you have Apple devices, and better an iPhone. According to a survey by the dating site Match.com U.S. citizens are more picky when it comes to dating other people. And if you have an Android then you might be out of luck. The survey questions more than 5.500 single people and the findings are pretty interesting. So survey showed that Apple users are more likely to judge negatively Android users while people who use an Android are 15 times more likely to say something bad about iPhone owners. And if you have an old smartphone then you might not get a date at all. Abby Rodman psychotherapist in Boston says: â€œWe look for so many other ways in which weâ€™re compatible with potential partners, why shouldnâ€™t phones be on the list?â€ â€œWhere a person lives, what car they drive, and what they do for a living are all things we weigh before embarking on a relationship. That may be pitiful commentary, but weâ€™re also looking for compatibility in the non-materialistic: political viewpoints, religious convictions, and fundamental ethical values.â€ Also, Simon Rego, chief psychologist at Montefiore Medical Center talked about technology and dating: â€œThe metrics of the traditional date have shifted,â€ says He does see a cultish aspect to the technology we use. â€œSome people would rather lose their sense of smell than their iPhones. Itâ€™s as important to spell-check your text as it is to straighten your tie. Actually, Iâ€™m not sure people even wear ties on dates anymore.â€ And if you spend too much time on social media that can be a no0no for some singles. When the time comes to â€œbefriendâ€ someone on Facebook and arrange a date then your use of social media might determine if you will go on with the date. And it is a bit ironic if you think about it. If some people judge others by their smartphone and arrange online dates then the use of social media might not be such a huge problem. Abby Rodman also says about the matter: â€œIf youâ€™re living every breath of your life out loud on social media, you may be perceived as not being reliable enough to honor the sanctity of anotherâ€™s confidence or of a romantic relationship.â€ Despite the smartphone differences both Apple and Android users have some things in common when it comes to dating. Almost 15% of people who are dating wonâ€™t date someone with a cracked smartphone screen, it added. Also, bad grammar, discolored teeth and poor fashion choices are among the list. This is an issue that Facebook is combating and has gotten quite a lot of blame for, and it looks like Apple wants to nip it in the bud quickly before the spotlight falls onto them. As you know, Apple has a News app of their own and during a recent interview, Appleâ€™s internet service chief Eddy Cue revealed the companyâ€™s plans to combat fake news on their end. According to Cue, â€œWe wanted Apple News to be available to everyone, but we want to vet and make sure that the news providers are legitimate. Weâ€™re very concerned about all of the news items and the clickbait from that standpoint, and that driving a lot of the news coverage. Weâ€™re trying to do some things in Apple News, weâ€™re learning from that and we need to share that together as an industry and improve it.â€ He also revealed that because a lot of news these days are being read through such apps and devices, that Apple feels that they do have a responsibility for ensuring that the content delivered is the real deal. However as to what exactly Apple will be doing was not revealed, but itâ€™s good to know that they are looking into it. Filed in Apple. Read more about Apps and iOS. Apple reportedly signs new 60-million-panel deal with Samsung By Vlad Dudau News Editor Neowin LLC @avladd Â· Feb 13, 2017 with 28 comments The iPhone 6S Plus uses an LCD display, while most modern flagships use AMOLED For years now, Apple has been expected to make the transition from LED to OLED panels in its smartphones. These rumors recently intensified as numerous sources within the industry pointed to the iPhone maker adopting OLED displays for at least one of its iPhone models coming out later this year. Samsung has been part of these rumors for a long time as well, because its subsidiary, Samsung Display, creates most of the available OLED panels used in todayâ€™s smartphones, and is one of the few companies able to churn out the number of panels Apple would require. Last year, sources inside the Korean electronics giant, not to mention its own public financial records, pointed to a massive deal signed between Samsung Display and a third party, believed to be Apple. According to reports at the time, the deal would see Samsung Display provide Apple with 100 million OLED display panels, starting this year. Now, a new deal between the two companies seems to have been made, according to Korean media. The new arrangement will see Samsung supply a further 60 million panels to Apple, significantly boosting Samsung Displayâ€™s share of the iPhone-makerâ€™s business. Considering Apple sold around 200 million iPhones over its last four quarters, 160 million OLED displays seems like a huge number. The size of that order appears even more surprising in the context of recent rumors pointing to just one iPhone model, the 10-year anniversary edition, having an OLED display, while two further â€œregularâ€ models were expected to continue using LCD technology. This increased order, which hasnâ€™t been officially confirmed by either of the two companies, might point to Apple deciding to use OLED panels in more of its products. Or it might point to the company being extremely optimistic about the rumored 10th-anniversary iPhone. In either case, with the next iPhone still half a year away, weâ€™ll just have to wait until further information becomes available. Features Reviews Phones Android iPhone Windows Phone Apps Computers Laptops Lenovo Tablets Windows Tutorials Events More Audio Crowfunding Design/Concepts Gadgets Gaming General Photo/Video Web Ubergizmo in French Ubergizmo in German Ubergizmo in Italian Ubergizmo in Spanish Apple Reportedly Orders 160 Million OLED Displays From Samsung By Tyler Lee on 02/14/2017 03:42 PST One of the rumored features of this yearâ€™s iPhone is that it will see Apple finally switch to an OLED display. However one of the recent reports have suggested that due to shortages, the OLED iPhone will be limited to a particular model of the iPhone 8 Plus variety, meaning that Appleâ€™s other iPhones will continue to use LCD. However a new report out of Korea from The Investor (via Cult of Mac) is painting a very different picture. If the reports are true, it seems that Apple has ordered an additional 60 million OLEDs from Samsung. This is on top of a previously rumored agreement in which Samsung would supply Apple with 100 million OLED panels for the iPhone 8. Now 160 million is obviously not a small figure to scoff at, and like we said it seems to contradict the earlier claims that the OLED screen would be exclusive to the iPhone 8 Plus. Given that Apple typically sells about 200 million iPhones a year, 160 million means that it accounts for 80% of iPhone sales, meaning that it seems unlikely that all 160 million orders are just for one particular model. In any case take it with a grain of salt for now, but this could possibly be good news for would-be customers who do not plan to purchase the larger Plus model, but would still like an OLED screen anyway. AirPods Review Wireless future by Adam Cook on February 14, 2017 Details Â  Â  Thereâ€™s a distinct possibility that, no matter what I write here, youâ€™ve already made your mind up about Appleâ€™s AirPods. Whether itâ€™s how they look, or whatever else, but regardless, Iâ€™m here to tell you that I really, really like them. In fact, I kinda love them. Theyâ€™re fancy tech, for sure, and not cheap. Know in advance that I like the packed in earbuds Apple usually supplied with iPhones. In fact, know that I think thereâ€™s a strange snobbery around them in many circles, despite the fact that thousands upon thousands of people use them quite happily every day, and never find reason to complain. Look, I know that you can buy headphones for hundreds of pounds that have superior audio quality (Iâ€™ve reviewed some excellent, and expensive headphones in my time), and I do firmly believe that you get what you pay for. I will say though: I like, and regularly use the stock Apple EarPods, and for a pair of headphones that come in the box, they provide pretty damn fine audio quality â€“ I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s because they are â€œfreeâ€, but theyâ€™re nowhere near as bad as people say. Letâ€™s not beat around the bush then, because the AirPods are an improvement, audio-wise. Not a giant leap, but they do sound slightly better. Nuances in the music seem clearer, whereas the bass and treble seem mostly the same. This is a clarity thing, with the moments in music you might otherwise lose coming through in the mix, and thatâ€™s a good thing. I think itâ€™s also worth mentioning that I have always found the EarPods comfortable, and the AirPods are no different. Interestingly, passing them round the house, it seems everyone agrees with me, and my wife (notorious in our house for saying buds are too big or too small, sheâ€™s the Goldilocks of headphones) found them comfortable as well. Iâ€™ve used bluetooth buds before, and the fact these have been designed by Apple, for Apple products, is very apparent. They just work, flawlessly so. Open the included case near your phone and the device will recognise them and offer to pair them. From there, itâ€™s clever, yet simple design all the way: put one Pod in, the music will go from your phone to the Pod. Put the second one in, itâ€™ll now be in stereo. Take a Pod out? Itâ€™ll pause the music. Put it back in? Yep, it starts playing again. Such simplicity is welcomed, and in the settings for your AirPods you can choose whether a double tap of the AirPod stem activates Siri, or pauses your music. In other words, if you donâ€™t fancy taking a Pod out to pause, or using a button on your phone or watch (whatever, really), you can double tap your headphones to pause whatever is playing. If thereâ€™s a minor complaint here, itâ€™s that you canâ€™t turn the audio up or down like you could with a normal pair of headphones, but the chances are that if youâ€™re spending Â£180 on them, youâ€™ve probably got an Apple Watch or iPhone which means you can still do it very quickly. The included case is also a charger, believe it or not. The case itself holds 24 hours of charge, while the AirPods themselves go for around five hours without needing to go back in. The truly impressive thing is that popping them back in the case for 10-15 minutes will give you another 2-3 hours of charge. Again, at the risk of repeating myself, this is impressive tech. The case itself charges via Lightning connector, as usual. In fact, as I write this, I havenâ€™t charged the case for three days, and I wear the AirPods for hours every day: ultimately, youâ€™re going to be incredibly unlucky if you find yourself with them not charged. Waxing lyrical to a colleague, the question I got asked was: â€œbut surely youâ€™ll lose them?â€. Thatâ€™s a fair question, but Iâ€™d counter with: â€œdo you lose your stock Apple EarPods?â€. No, because theyâ€™re cabled, the conversation continues, but I found running with the AirPods, and general gym-exercise was absolutely fine. If youâ€™re going to treat them with a lack of respect and throw them down wherever you fancy, sure, you might lose them in the same you might lose your keys. But the supplied charging case is smaller than a packet of tic-tacs, and goes in your pocket just fine. When youâ€™re not using them, put them in there and youâ€™ll keep them safe. Itâ€™s like any other expensive tech: look after it and itâ€™ll stay safe. While Iâ€™ll never be able to convince you if youâ€™ve already made your mind up, the future does appear to be wireless. The AirPods are comfy, sound great, and yes, theyâ€™re not the cheapest bluetooth headphones out there, but for a set that just work with your existing setup, I canâ€™t recommend them highly enough. Oh, and they look fine on, as well, donâ€™t let people tell you otherwise. The AirPods are now my go-to pair of headphones, and they feel like magic. scrolling="no" frameborder="0" style="border:none; overflow:hidden; width:80px; height:62px;" allowTransparency="true"> Positives Comfortable Impressive charge time Great audio Premium build quality Negatives No wireless way to change volume Not cheap Editor Rating Â  Our Score 9.5 SCORE OUT OF TEN 9.5 In Short Â  The AirPods are comfy, sound great, and yes, they're not the cheapest bluetooth headphones out there, but for a set that just work with your existing setup, I can't recommend them highly enough. 1 like Reviews, Tech appleApple AirPodsfeat Newly Added Halo Wars 2 Review 9.0 Â  How to Survive 2 ReviewÂ  Mario Sports Superstars is shaping up to be a lot of funÂ  Victor Vran: Overkill Edition announcedÂ  Alwaâ€™s Awakening ReviewÂ  Latest Reviews Halo Wars 2 Review 9.0 Â  How to Survive 2 ReviewÂ  Alwaâ€™s Awakening ReviewÂ  Apple AirPods ReviewÂ  Divide ReviewÂ  Random Video Latest PODCAST Podcast: Like a blade to the chest (08/02/17) Full Story Â  9.0 Halo Wars 2 Review by Gary Baileyon February 16, 2017 Halo? Recently during an interview with The Independent, Cook once again reiterated Appleâ€™s interest in the technology and stated how he believes that it is a â€œbig ideaâ€ just like the smartphone once was. According to Cook, â€œI regard it as a big idea like the smartphone. The smartphone is for everyone, we donâ€™t have to think the iPhone is about a certain demographic, or country or vertical market: itâ€™s for everyone. I think AR is that big, itâ€™s huge. I get excited because of the things that could be done that could improve a lot of lives. And be entertaining.â€ Cook also revealed why he believes that AR is better than VR. â€œMost people donâ€™t want to lock themselves out from the world for a long period of time and today you canâ€™t do that because you get sick from it. With AR you can, not be engrossed in something, but have it be a part of your world, of your conversation. That has resonance.â€ Itâ€™s interesting that Cook is so excited about the technology. This has previously led to speculation that Apple could have AR plans. The company has acquired companies that dealt with AR in the past, so it wouldnâ€™t be surprising if they were to eventually integrate it into some of their products in the future. Filed in Apple. This happened after Goldman Sachs said that Apple was slightly undervalued based on hearing speculation about the device possibly having AR features, signaling it may be a significant update to the iPhone. The price of the stock had been steadily rising after Apple's 2016 Q4 earnings call. The highest price of AppleÂ’s stock during a business day was $134.54 per share, which the closing date has not yet reached. Many investors Apple usually buy stock during the building up of rumors and leaks until around the time that a new iPhone is announced; thatÂ’s why youÂ’ll see a drastic shift in stock prices every year around September. Back in 2014, stock kept rising even a couple of months after the iPhone 6 came out, though it was a significant upgrade over the iPhone 5. Maybe not something along the lines of the Amazon Fire Phone parallax effect throughout the UI, but maybe Apple will put the feature to a useful application. We hit the headline numbers, key metrics, and dig through management's comments to catch all the info investors need to know. Sarah Priestley and Dylan Lewis (TMFSarahp) Feb 14, 2017 at 12:11PM Two big heavyweights of the tech industry, PayPalÂ (NASDAQ:PYPL) and AlphabetÂ (NASDAQ:GOOG) (NASDAQ:GOOGL), reported their fourth-quarter results earlier this month, and Motley Fool analysts Dylan Lewis and Sarah Priestley have dug through the reports. In this episode of Industry Focus: Tech, they share the most interesting points from both reports, from the most important earnings numbers to little Q&A gems that shed some light on each companies' long-term plans, and more.Â  A full transcript follows the video. This podcast was recorded on Jan. 27, 2017. Dylan Lewis:Â Welcome to Industry Focus, the podcast that dives into a different sector of the stock market every day. It'sÂ Friday, Jan. 27, and we're breaking themÂ quarterly results fromÂ PayPalÂ andÂ Alphabet. I'm your host, Dylan Lewis,Â and I'm joined in the studio by fool.comÂ tech editor Sarah Priestley. Sarah,Â how's it going? Sarah Priestley:Â It's good,Â it's a pleasure to be here, thank you for having me. Lewis: AreÂ you excited for pizza day? Priestley:Â I am very excited. It'sÂ going to derail my New Year's resolutions,Â but that's OK.Â [laughs]Â  Lewis: That's a callback to yourÂ episode with the Vincent Shen. Are you finding that the Apple Watch is being helpful? Priestley:Â Yes. It'sÂ definitely reminding me at 9 p.m. that I have done 0 steps,Â so I just end up walking around my living roomÂ like a crazy person. Lewis: I do that when I'm on the phone all the time. That'sÂ how I get my exercise in. Priestley:Â That'sÂ probably a good idea, yeah. Lewis: So,Â Sarah, a ton going on in techÂ this week, the next couple weeks with earnings. Two pretty followed FoolÂ companies reported yesterday after the bell. We dug into the reports andÂ are ready to talk about them. You didÂ some of the heavy lifting with PayPal; I dug into Alphabet. Why don't weÂ talk about PayPal first. How did the results look? Priestley:Â To give you an overview for the fourth quarter,Â earnings came in at $0.42 per share. $2.9 billion in revenue. Operating revenue was a littleÂ higher than expected at 21%. Transactions were $1.8 billion. But the volume wasÂ below expected. Expected was $100 billion and they delivered $99.3 billion. And that is why share prices are down about 3.5% this morning. So,Â it seems like a slight overreactionÂ when you dig into their numbers. But, yeah,Â that's the reason for the share price falling. Lewis: And that's really one of the core metrics that investors tend to focus on for them as a company, right? Priestley:Â Absolutely. They really areÂ measured on engagement, soÂ number of customers, and engagement of those customers,Â and the key metrics for those. Lewis: Looking beyond some of the top line numbers,Â what else popped up to you in the report? Priestley:Â TheÂ operating margin for the fourth quarter was down to 15.4%. The reason that we'reÂ commenting on this is that that's a lot,Â it takes up a lot of roomÂ in the bullish theses,Â that the new partnerships they've started withÂ a lot of the banks,Â Visa,Â Mastercard, they're going to really pressure their margins down. Lewis: Is the thought there that they're working with very big institutions and big players, and they just don'tÂ have the negotiating room that they might with some smaller players?Â  Priestley:Â Absolutely. That's part of it. And also,Â it's just the standard transaction payment. It'sÂ the same thing forÂ SquareÂ and other payment processors; it's a standard transaction amount on card processing. So, thatÂ 15.4% compared to 16.1%Â in the fourth quarter of last year -- you can see, that's quite a decline there. Management has talked about the fact that they are really doing everything they can to leverage their other income against this. And I feel like they've done a pretty good job. Their CEO, DanÂ Schulman,Â has said that they won't be a slave to quarter-to-quarter margin performance. Lewis: Which isÂ something we like to hear as Foolish investors. Priestley:Â That'sÂ very true. And,Â I would also comment thatÂ the management team is reallyÂ being driven for their compensation package on theÂ long-term performance of this stock,Â and I think that really shows in their reporting. They'reÂ focused on free cash flow in theirÂ projects, and what they're delivering to their customers. Just to give you a couple of the year-over-year figures: Earnings per share for the yearÂ increased 15% to $1.15. Non-GAAP was $1.50 on guidance of $1.45 to $1.50. That's pretty good. Revenue for the full year was up 17%, and 21% on a currency-neutral basis, and they guided for 19%, so they really beat that. Lewis: Like Alphabet, theirÂ fiscal Q4 comesÂ with the calendar Q4, soÂ we were able to look at full year results here,Â and not just the quarterly results. What's going on with total payment volume?Â I know that's something that people really like to focus on with them. Priestley:Â Yeah,Â absolutely.Â If we had seen total payment volume less than 25%,Â I think we would have seen a bigger decline in the stock price. Luckily, for the fourth quarter,Â payment volume was up 25%. As I said, theÂ actual processed amount was $99.3 billion, which missed the expectations. Interestingly, the majority of this was pushed by international. InternationalÂ expanded 27%. The U.S. was 23%.Â  Lewis: AndÂ for theÂ unacquainted, total payment volume is justÂ the gross amount that they areÂ helping to facilitate. Priestley:Â Yes. The way to look at this is,Â the total payment volume is the number ofÂ payments that they process. Then, the transaction is the amount that they process. So, they'reÂ averaging about $56 per transaction right now. That'sÂ slightly down from $60 that they were averaging a couple quarters ago. ButÂ it's still very good. Lewis: So, for the amount per transaction to be down, theyÂ must be doing more total transactionsÂ to be making it up in volumeÂ and still be seeing growth, right? Priestley:Â Yes,Â you're exactly right.Â I will also comment that, of their transactions in their Q4, $100 billion was mobile payments, which is an increase of 55%, and it's almost a third now of their transactions processed. Which is fantastic, and I think the management team has really isolated that as an opportunity for the company. That's where they're going to really demonstrate their industry leadership. The market is moving toward mobile, and they're really pioneering in the mobile industry. Lewis: So what can people expect looking forward, either first quarterÂ of 2017 orÂ further out, broadly in 2017? Priestley:Â Absolutely. I'll look for 2017Â quarter four revenue we're expecting to growÂ on a currency neutral basisÂ 16% to 18%. That gives you a range of $2.9 billion to $2.95 billion. That wasÂ actuallyÂ slightly more conservative thanÂ some analysts were expecting, which played into their share priceÂ performance today. But full-year performance is strong, revenue growth 15% to 17% and 17% to 19% currency neutral, which gives you about $12.45 billion to $12.65 billion. Lewis: Is thereÂ anything to worry about withÂ some of these numbers that we're looking at, thatÂ management growth projections are different thanÂ what the market is expecting? Because,Â they are still very much in growth mode as a business, and I know that early on, those projections, if they start to decelerate at all, can start to scare people off a little bit. Priestley:Â I think they have been fairly conservativeÂ in some of their estimations,Â because they really do have a huge potential with the mobile traffic. I think,Â if you look at some of their projects that they'reÂ working on now, Venmo has increased 100% year over year. It wasÂ Time Magazine'sÂ best app, it's processed $5.6 billion, which was up 126%. So,Â I think they have aÂ huge potential with a lot of the projects they're working on; they'veÂ experienced huge growth. The problem with these is that they are not monetized yet. And anÂ analyst actually raised the question in the earnings call: "Is yourÂ projection in 2017 building inÂ some of the expectations forÂ monetizing this, and also Xoom?" which is their international money transfer program. They dismissed this. They saidÂ it was pushing out to 2018, some of theÂ opportunities,Â and that they will be focused on growth. So, I think,Â for 2017, these might be conservative estimates. But for 2018,Â we might actually start to seeÂ the fruits of that labor. Lewis: Yeah, and you said, 55% ofÂ what was being processed, broadly for the business, wasÂ coming from mobile. When you look at Venmo specifically,Â that is almost entirely mobile. It's more peer-to-peer. There areÂ some questions about whether or not they will be able to monetize that very well,Â and what that might look like, because me giving you $5 becauseÂ you bought me lunch the other day, they don't really take anything on that. Priestley:Â No,Â they don't. AndÂ something to say is,Â it's becoming a hugely crowded market. I thinkÂ PayPal, to some degree, has a first-mover advantage, but they'reÂ definitely not the biggest player in this industry. The banks have gotten together and created clearXchange, which is a peer-to-peerÂ payment which is also free right now. It'sÂ owned by the banks, so it has a lot of clout. Whether or not people pick it up to the rate that they've picked up Venmo, which isÂ hugely popular with millennials, a lot of our friends use it all the time, we use it. Also,Â Apple. Apple has grown hugely. Tim Cook in his last earnings call -- so,Â this is a bit outdated -- said thatÂ 75% ofÂ swiping transactions were from Apple Pay. Lewis: Wow. It'sÂ hard to believe.Â Anecdotally, though, when I'm out with my friends,Â and maybe you can lend some color on this too, if someone covers the tab,Â I'm paying them via Venmo. No one is ever like, "Do you haveÂ Bank of AmericaÂ mobile payment processing?" So, they do seem to have that first-moverÂ advantage, and I think they have that name recognition. When you have that huge installed base, as they do, it really comes down to whether they can flip the monetization switch on. I guess investors areÂ going to have to be patient on that, ifÂ management is pushing that out to 2018. Priestley:Â Absolutely. I will say,Â they do have a lot of initiatives that are panning out for them right now. One TouchÂ basically enables youÂ to fill in your bank details, and you work through PayPal,Â and you can just click one button at the checkout and it's transacted throughÂ PayPal, which is hugely beneficial for mobile.Â I don't know about you, but frequently, when I'mÂ  looking at shoes online, as soon as I get toÂ the card payment, and you have to zoom in on those small boxes and put your card numbers in, they lose me. I think it's something like aÂ 74% cart-abandonment rate on mobile. Lewis: So whenÂ people reach that checkout phase and theyÂ see that they need to drop in their credit card number, their security code, their address, shipping address, zip code, all that stuff,Â they wind up ditching it? Priestley:Â Absolutely. But, PayPal One Touch,Â they have 87% conversion rate on mobile. That's incredible. They've hadÂ a lot of people starting to use that. They have added a lot of One Touch users. And, I think, of their merchants, about one-third right now are on One Touch. And they just launched this last year. So there's a hugeÂ potential here for them to really deliver on their promise. They've said they want to make customers' lives easier, and they're doing that, absolutely. Lewis: Anything else thatÂ management provided color on with the business, andÂ strategically where they're looking, thatÂ investors should know? Priestley:Â I think the focus is absolutely on mobile. Dan Schulman hasÂ definitely commented on the fact that mobile is the biggestÂ opportunity for them, and there are a lot of industry tailwinds that they're experiencing right now. AndÂ I would completely agree. I thinkÂ Black Friday this year was the biggest online shopping day in history. InÂ quarter three last year -- we're still waiting for quarter four --Â the Census Bureau said thatÂ online retail made up 10% of all retail transactions. So you can see that if they are positioning themselves well to benefit from this, it should be a rising tide that lifts all boats. Lewis: I know they'veÂ talked a little bit in the past aboutÂ continuing to be an asset-light business. Is that something that management recommitted to inÂ the most recent call? Priestley:Â Yeah,Â absolutely. This is something that analysts have been focusing on. I definitely noticed a couple of questions about this in the earnings call. Square offers capital, it offers loans, as part of its services. It's not a huge part of their business, but it is a risk area of the business. So, in the fourth quarter, they had $123 million loss on loans. As a service similar to the company Square, which deals mostly with small businesses, but obviously this is individuals, PayPal has access to a lot of people's information and their spending habits and how much money they have. So they want to really leverage that information, and offer it out to partners to facilitate the loans using their information, which takes the risk away from PayPal, but they're still generating a percentage of income from it. So, overall, Dan SchulmanÂ commented that it's a really competitive environment for this. I think the payment space isÂ just getting more and more competitive, every angle of it. ButÂ overall, I think this is definitely a good moveÂ for the company. It's the right decision,Â it's going to eliminate some risk. ButÂ it's also potentially going to bring in a degree ofÂ revenue too, if they can grow that segment. Lewis: So,Â it seems like the general takeaway here is: Wait and see with a lot of the company'sÂ mobile initiatives. The core businessÂ seems to be humming along. There was a little bit of disappointment,Â but nothing thesis-altering,Â nothing crazy in the report. Priestley:Â No,Â absolutely not. And they didn't touch too much onÂ some of their partners. They've had some really high-profileÂ partnerships withÂ Alibaba, VodafoneÂ in the U.K. and Europe, and many others; Discover, that they recentlyÂ announced. They didn't touch on that too much, so we can't really give investors a good flavor for how that's going, only that it's in line with theirÂ expectations. So,Â yeah, I agree with what you said. I thinkÂ mobile is going to be a big area of focus, we'll continue to have a look at those transaction volumes and customer engagement. Lewis:Â SoÂ Sarah,Â I said that you did the heavy lifting on PayPal. I did most of the homework with Alphabet's earnings.Â I'm going to flip it over to you and let you host for the second half of the show. Priestley:Â It'sÂ really nice to not be in the hot seat.Â [laughs]Â  Lewis: Yeah.Â I'll stop firing questions at you. It's my turn. Priestley:Â So, yeah, AlphabetÂ reported the same time, yesterday after the bell. What were the results? Lewis: Overall, Alphabet'sÂ revenue came in at about $26.1 billion for Q4, up 22% year over year, which beat analysts' estimates of $25.3 billion. Earnings per share came in at $7.56, slightly lower than analysts' projections of $7.63 per share. I think the real story -- and what caused some of theÂ immediate reaction for the stock -- was that adjusted profit missed by much more. That came in at $9.36 a share, versus expectations of $9.64 a share. We saw, after hours, the stock was down about 2.5% to 3%. That's what most of the market seemed to really fixate on. Priestley:Â And what was the cause of that? Lewis: Tax rate, basically, is the short of it. In Q4, Alphabet had an effective tax rate of 22%. They also highlighted their broad 2016 tax rate, because they're able to report whole fiscal year results as well. The company's effective tax rate for the year was 19%. That's a big bump. And you realize that average is also incorporating other quarters. You can get a sense of how much more they were paying out in taxes this quarter. Really, if you want to get down to the nitty-gritty,Â MarketWatchÂ writer Jeremy Owen doesÂ a really good job breaking down the specifics, butÂ the gist of the issue is,Â the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued some changes a while back,Â basically impactingÂ how companies can treat stock-based compensation for their adjusted earnings numbers. And that wound up impacting results for this quarter. Moving forward, the company willÂ no longer be excluding stock-based compensation expenses from their non-GAAP results, which should smooth things out. But they wound up dealing with a little bit of a hiccup this quarter to reconcile. Priestley:Â Yeah, that'sÂ really unusual, the change for GAAP there. Lewis: Yeah. Typically, you think of non-GAAP numbers as beingÂ something where the Financial Accounting Standards Board gives people aÂ decent amount of latitude to operate how they want to. ButÂ they like to rein things in every now and then,Â specifically with stock-based compensation because it's something that a lot of firms use to make their non-GAAP numbers look quite a bit better than their GAAPÂ numbers, especially in the tech space. Looking atÂ a couple of the different segments, their GoogleÂ segment, which is search, ads,Â Android, Maps, Chrome, YouTube,Â pretty much anything that falls under their internet properties, came in at $25.8 billion. So,Â looking at a company with $26 billion in quarterly revenue, that's the meat of it right there. That isÂ generally performing pretty well. Their Google Sites segment, which is theÂ majority of that, was up 20% year over year. Network revenue up 7% year over year. Other revenue, which is a smaller portionÂ a little bit less related to the internet properties within that segment -- thinkÂ Hardware, Google Play, and their cloud segment -- was $3.4 billion, which was up 62% year over year. So,Â that's a very fast-growing segment withinÂ Sundar Pichai's Google area of the business. I think,Â if you're looking for indicators for them, the two big ones that tell the story for the ad business and what's going on with some of the internet properties: Aggregate paid clicks, which is basically theÂ number of times that people are interacting with ads online, was up 36% year over year. Aggregate cost per click, or CPCs, as they're commonly known, was down 15% year over year. This isÂ not really a surprise. This is a story that's beenÂ playing out for a long time. WeÂ talked about the shift to mobile when we wereÂ talking about PayPal. The same thing is happening with internet search. CPCs have been driven downÂ because the effectiveness ofÂ mobile ads isn't necessarily quite the same as it is for desktop. But for the longest time, Google has been able to make it up on volume. There'sÂ actually quite a parallel there withÂ what happened with PayPal and theÂ volume making up for the smaller transactions. We'reÂ seeing the same effects here with Alphabet. Priestley:Â Would you suggest that'sÂ something that investors should include in their thesis going forward? Lewis: I think it's something that, atÂ this point, we shouldn't be too surprised by. This story has been playing out for a decent amount of time. If it reallyÂ accelerates, you might have to worry. But they have been very good atÂ making the volume make it work out. Eventually, mobile will need to find a floor somewhere, and enjoy that. But so long as we're still in thatÂ transition to mobile,Â I think we're going to continue to see this for a while, unfortunately. Priestley:Â OK. What about the Other BetsÂ segment? I know there have been some interesting moves this year. Lewis: Yeah, this isÂ something that people love to ask about, because it's like, "Where isÂ Google wasting all of this money?" As a reminder, this is basically all the stuff they do that isn't tied to theirÂ internet properties. Think of it as their moonshot projects. The big financial contributors for this segment are Nest, Fiber, and Verily. They tend toÂ focus on a full-year breakoutÂ for the segmentÂ because the numbers are so smallÂ relative to the overall business. But revenue came in at $809 million for 2016, which was upÂ 82% year over year. Operating lossÂ not including stock-based compensation was $2.9 billion, down slightly year over year. But, thisÂ segment is still a money pit for Alphabet, and I think it willÂ continue to be. They have reined in costsÂ a little bit under CFO Ruth Porat. I think she has forced all of the Other BetsÂ initiatives toÂ at least be able to show a path to monetization, or a road map toÂ what that might look like. But I think there's a certain test-and-innovateÂ atmosphere that they want to maintain. AndÂ investors have been OK with that, because their core internet business just prints money for them. Something that isÂ interesting with them and the Other Bets segment is, they spun outÂ Waymo, which is their autonomous drivingÂ segment. For the longest time, that was the Google Self-Driving Car Project. A couple months ago, they said, "This is a stand-alone business unit, and it will be nested within the Alphabet holding structure. It will continue to be in Other Bets." AndÂ we didn't get any financial insight into what's going on with that. But they talked about it in the call. Ruth PoratÂ provided some commentary on what they'reÂ basically doing with Waymo as a blueprint for what they will continue to be doing with Other Bets. Not a ton to report there,Â but this is something that Daniel Sparks and IÂ talked about in a podcast when they announced that a few months ago. As we, in the next couple quarters, overÂ the next year, continue to get more information about Waymo,Â I think we can look at that specific business segment and see the path forÂ what's going to be going on for some of the Other Bets as theyÂ continue to mature and eventually see monetization. So, not a ton to report with Other Bets stuff, butÂ at least we have something that we can start to track for what the company's ambitions might be. Priestley:Â Absolutely. ItÂ looks like they're moving forward with that. Was thereÂ anything else in the numbers that stood out to you in the earnings call? Lewis:Â I thinkÂ some of the things that people need to keep in mindÂ with this report,Â because the stock was down after hours, I thinkÂ as of taping this morning, they were down 40 or 50 basis points,Â so not a crazy reaction like 3% that we sawÂ after hours yesterday, but still down,Â I think people might be scratching their heads a little bit with some of the tax stuff they saw. Prior to the report,Â the company was trading at all-time highs. It'sÂ traded up for a while. I think it's somewhere in the teens in the last year or so. So, there's that. AndÂ also, Alphabet does not provide detailedÂ quarterly guidance. MostÂ companies do offer up that guidance, and analysts create their ownÂ models based on those numbers, those line items, and they have theirÂ puts and takes toÂ tweak it slightly. But because Alphabet doesn't giveÂ those baseline expectations, theÂ likelihood of actual numbers beingÂ different than analysts expectations isÂ slightly higher than it would beÂ for other companies. So, the market's reactionÂ is always, I think, generally going to beÂ a little bit sharper than what we might seeÂ for a company that does offer standard guidance. Priestley:Â Yeah,Â because they have nothing readyÂ to peg their estimates to. Lewis: Yeah. They haveÂ the general trend of thingsÂ and what they can glean from commentary. ButÂ very often, you'll seeÂ analysts' expectations more or less mirror guidance withÂ slight adjustments. Not having that as a crutchÂ can just add some unpredictability to things. I think that's the way you have to think about it. Priestley:Â Any other little gems? Lewis: Outside of theÂ numbers, something that caught my eye that I think is a great point, andÂ really underscores the importanceÂ of reading company conference calls, andÂ not just relying on the numbers that you see reportedÂ and the quick earnings takes you'll see online: Mark Mahaney fromÂ RBC Capital MarketsÂ in the Q&AÂ section of the call asked thisÂ really great question, and I think it points to a looming risk forÂ Alphabet, and I just want to highlight that for listeners. He said, "ItÂ looks to me like Google devices are being outsold 10 to 1 orÂ something like that in most homes. It's immaterial now,Â but you could see you in five yearsÂ there's a new voice search interaction interfaceÂ and it's not Google in the home. ThatÂ could be a real challenge for the company." AndÂ he was basically positing, "What are you guys doing about all of the virtual-assistant and smart-home devices?" Priestley:Â Yeah,Â great question. Lewis: Yeah. AndÂ Sundar Pichai,Â Google CEO,Â he gave that generally positive answer,Â talking about the investments the company is makingÂ and how they're working toward voice search, and how they're trying to meet consumersÂ in every situation that they might be using voice search,Â whether it be phones, TV, homes, cars, whatever. But really, at its core, Mahaney's question isÂ getting at this idea of: Amazon's EchoÂ devices are selling like hotcakes. If the installed base for them,Â or really any other virtual assistant, getsÂ massive, and consumers start using those devicesÂ for the types of things and the purposes thatÂ people are generally using Google mobile andÂ desktop search for,Â what does that do for your business? I don't want to be alarmist with any of this. I am an Alphabet shareholder,Â I really love the company. But I think he makes a good point. Earlier this month, actually, at an ad industryÂ conference, there was an AmazonÂ VPÂ talking about some of the capabilitiesÂ and some of the opportunitiesÂ that Amazon might explore. That ledÂ some analysts to speculate thatÂ the company might be interested in exploring paid search with its Alexa product. This is not something that is a next-quarter, next-year issue. But over the next five to 10 years,Â we need to keep an eye on how people are using search, andÂ how people are using home assistants orÂ virtual assistants. Because,Â if we see that slowly eat intoÂ what would otherwise be desktop or mobile search,Â you have to wonder about how that mightÂ impact Google's core business, and reallyÂ what prints money for them and allows them to fundÂ all of these other projects. Priestley:Â Yeah. And also, which products they're using. IfÂ everybody starts adopting the Google Nest, then they're good. Lewis: Yeah. If people are using Nest or GoogleÂ Assistant, then yeah, not a huge problem,Â that will keep them within that ecosystem. If they are using products that don't lean onÂ Google search, and you have platforms that areÂ able to monetize that search,Â Google might get crowded out a little bit. Again, Google did $26 billion in revenue this quarter. TheÂ vast majority of that was online ads. It's a huge market. I think people's more in-depth searching, or more research-based stuff, isÂ always going to be on desktop or mobile. You can only glean so much from audio. ButÂ if you want the quick answer on something -- sayÂ you want to know who was the fifth president of the United States --Â you can find that out with a voice search,Â and not really have to worry about being on mobile or desktop. And that's less impressions for Google Ad Search. So, it'sÂ something to keep in mind. Again, this is a five, 10-year risk. But, just,Â investors, keep an eye on what's going onÂ with the virtual assistant market,Â because it's something that could impact Alphabet down the road. Priestley:Â That's really interesting.Â I will hand the baton back to you.Â [laughs]Â  Lewis: Oh,Â you're going to let me wrap up? That'sÂ so magnanimous of you. Well, listeners, thatÂ does it for this episode of Industry Focus. If you have any questions, or just want to reach out and say "hey," shoot us an email at industryfocus@fool.com. Navigation Home News / Articles App Reviews Accessory Reviews Podcast TiP Us Join the TiP team HOT TOPICS: iPhone 8 TV app AirPods MacBook Pro with Touch Bar iPad Pro You are here: Home > Appleâ€™s a â€˜contributing sponsorâ€™ of BSides security conference in San Fransisco Appleâ€™s a â€˜contributing sponsorâ€™ of BSides security conference in San Fransisco February 13, 2017 Peter Cao Leave a comment The sponsor list for the BSides security conference in San Fransisco has been revealed and Apple is on the list. Joining other tech companies such as Google, and Dropbox, Apple is listed as a â€œcontributing sponsor.â€ Specifics as to what Apple will be doing as a sponsor is unclear at this time, but one of the event organizers tweeted that the company was providing free food for the day. Albeit, a small contribution, any form of contribution is notable for Apple. BSides is an annual event that is held at various cities around the country, serving as anÂ â€œopen forum for discussion and debate for security engineers and their affiliates.â€ BSides SF is a non-profit organization designed to advance the body of Information Security knowledge, by providing an annual, two day, open forum for discussion and debate for security engineers and their affiliates. We produce a conference that is a source of education, collaboration, and continued conversation for information technologists and those associated with this field. The technical and academic presentations at BSides SF are given in the spirit of peer review and advanced knowledge dissemination. This allows the field of Information Security to grow in breadth and depth, and continue in its pursuit of highly advanced scientifically based knowledge. Â  SOFTPEDIAÂ® DESKTOP Windows Games Drivers Mac Linux MOBILE Android APK Phones Tablets WEB Webscripts Web Browsers NEWS Softpedia > News > Apple FLASH SALE: Driver Booster 4 Â Â Â Â  40% OFF! Apple iPhone 8 Could Feature a Fingerprint Sensor Embedded into the Display GO Apple has patented several other similar methods before Feb 14, 2017 14:22 GMT Â Â·Â  By Alexandra Vaidos Â Â·Â  Share:Â  Last year, we reported that Apple filed a patent application for a fingerprint sensor built into the display and it seems that it wasnâ€™t the only such feature that the Cupertino giant patented. A new patent shows a method of embedding the fingerprint sensor into the screen. The patent application was filed back in 2014, which means that Apple had plenty of time to perfect the method and it might actually be featured on the iPhone 8. The upcoming iPhone 8 or iPhone X will mark the 10-year anniversary since the first iPhone was released. The smartphone is said to come with major design changes, tiny bezels, and even a slightly curved display. In order to achieve smaller bezels, Apple could very well remove the physical home button and place the fingerprint scanner below the display. The new method can only be used on OLED displays The new patent reveals just how Apple might do that. The smartphone could use infrared emitters and sensors placed alongside the RGB LEDs in an OLED-style display, according to Apple Insider. This would allow the reading of fingerprints through high-resolution touch sensing features. The patent also says that this method can only be used with an OLED display, which suggests that it might be featured on the iPhone 8 since the phone is said to come with such a screen type. The patent is assigned to Apple, but the technology was invented by LuxVue, a company that Apple bought in 2014. However, thereâ€™s no guarantee that Apple will actually develop the new technology, considering that the company has also patented two other methods. One of the past patents revealed a method of placing a sensor behind the screen and reading fingerprints through gaps in the space. In addition, thereâ€™s the option of using ultrasonic fingerprint scanner, namely Qualcomm's Snapdragon Sense ID, which utilizes ultrasonic waves instead. The iPhone 8 is also rumored to come with edge-to-edge display, wide-range wireless charging, and a bigger battery. #Apple#iPhone 8#Fingerprint sensor#OLED display#Touch ID subscribe feedly old reader newsblur digg reader rss feed reddit it! flip it share it tweet it Related Â Â·Â  Hot right now Â Â·Â  Latest news iPhone 8 to Squeeze 5.5-Inch iPhone Plus Battery in a 4.7-Inch Body iPhone 8 with Dual-Edge Display, Slim Bezels Imagined in Concept Video Apple Reportedly Paid Samsung $4.3 Billion for More iPhone OLED Displays Apple iPhone 8 Will Reportedly Feature Iris Scanner Apple Edges Out Samsung to Become Top Global Smartphone Vendor in Q4 Microsoft Extends Support for Original Windows 10 Version DebConf18 Will Be Hosted in Hsinchu, Taiwan, as First Debian Conference in Asia Moto G5 and G5 Plus Press Renders and Specs Revealed by Spanish Retailer Appleâ€™s iPhone 8 to Ditch Home Button in Favor of Virtual Capacitive Buttons No New Windows 10 Cumulative Updates Coming This Month After All Apple Edges Out Samsung to Become Top Global Smartphone Vendor in Q4 Microsoftâ€™s February Security Updates to Launch in March Â Â  Apple patent application for fingerprint scanner into the display new ios apps NeuroNation: Train your brain to improve your memory and focus with NeuroNation Flipagram: Create cool videos by mixing up your photos with music Timer+: Set up dozens of timers and control them all with ease Nutshell Camera: Create some pretty cool videos with Nutshell Camera IKEA Catalogue: Check out the IKEA Catalogue for more than just furniture Complete: Complete puts a social twist to your regular to-do list/ task manager WebMD Baby: WebMD Baby offers help in how to best tend to your baby Reader comments Appleâ€™s iPhone 8 to Ditch Home Button in Favor of Virtual Capacitive Buttons more on: Apple i softpediaÂ® Â  Â Â Like 202K Â Â Â +1 56K Â  Â Â Follow 13K Â© 2001-2017 Softpedia. TrustedReviews Facebook Twitter Googleplus TVs & Audio Cameras Computing Mobile Home appliances Gaming MWC 2017 Desktop PCs Internet Laptops Monitors PC Components Peripherals More Printers Software Trending: Nintendo Switch Apple Watch 2 iPhone 7 Galaxy S8 Google Pixel iPhone 8 Home / Opinions / Apple is breaking my heart with the Mac mini Apple is breaking my heart with the Mac mini by Michael Passingham 14 February 2017 0 shares Read Comments Opinion: On Valentine's Day, Computing Editor Michael Passingham ponders the merits of Appleâ€™s most unloved device, the Mac mini. One of the benefits of working for a big company is that you get a say in the type of computer you wish to use. I use a Lenovo ThinkPad, while many of my colleagues use MacBook Airs â€“ a decision that requires an opinion piece of its own to understand. Some folk choose Mac minis. They'll take their Mac mini out of their locker and carry it to their 'hot desk' for the day. At the end of each day, they'll unplug it and return it to their locker. I know, it's mind-boggling â€“ and in more ways than you might think. For one, it has been 854 days since Apple's last Mac mini update, or more than two years. In and of itself, the Mac mini's age isn't a problem, as you should generally be able to get at least three years out of a decent computer, and often many more. But what you won't see on any Apple spec sheet is the fact that its 'latest' Mac minis use Intel's 4th-generation 'Haswell' Core processors. These actually launched in July 2014, making the technology at the heart of the device positively ancient, at least in computer chip time. These processors are significantly less efficient and powerful than current-gen Intel CPUs, and even pale in comparison to the 5th-gen kit found in the seemingly abandoned MacBook Air. Compared to the 6th- and 7th-gen kit found in the latest 13-inch MacBook Pro? Don't get me started. Related: Intel Core i processors explained At Â£479, the Mac mini is the cheapest way to join the excellent macOS ecosystem; even the most expensive Mac mini model 'only' costs Â£949, which is less than you'll pay for a new MacBook Pro. Yet given its fossilised internals, you won't be making the most of what macOS Sierra has to offer. You donâ€™t get the benefits of a great touchpad, brilliant screen or backlit keyboard. You donâ€™t get processors powerful enough to do multimedia task particularly well, and the cheapest model also comes with just 4GB of RAM, plus you have to attach numerous cables to get the benefit of its desktop form factor. One argument in favour of the device is that it features more ports than all the MacBooks. This is true: it does have a pair of ThunderBolt/DisplayPort connectors and an HDMI port, along with four USB ports and an SD card slot. However, it canâ€™t output to a 4K monitor at more than a juddery 30Hz, making its high-res capability useless for many people. Itâ€™s lumped with slow hard disks in all but the most expensive model, which receives a slightly faster â€œFusionâ€ drive with a bit of solid state cache. But thereâ€™s no high-performance storage anywhere to be seen. What really irks me here is that the Mac mini has the potential to be a fantastic machine. Nowadays, you can quite happily squeeze a proper quad-core Intel processor into a compact PC chassis, rather than the piddly U-series dual cores in the Mac mini. Intelâ€™s Skull Canyon range of PCs, the stylish HP Pavilion Wave and the impressive Zotac Zbox Magnus, are but three examples of what can be achieved in a compact space. To dive a bit deeper, let's use the Pavilion Wave as our example. It's a complete PC that includes a built-in speaker, high-quality design, and components that are substantially faster than the Mac mini. Yet it costs, at most, Â£730 for 128GB of SSD storage, a 1TB hard disk and a proper quad-core i5 processor from Intelâ€™s sixth-gen range. Plus, it can output 4K at a full 60Hz. All this value from HP, a company that's aggressively pursuing Apple levels of flashy lifestyle kit. Against the odds, it's actually succeeding. Windows 10 may lag behind macOS in terms of ease of use, but HP's PC shows whatâ€™s possible in hardware terms. If Apple simply refreshed the Mac mini this year with the latest 7th-gen Intel Core processors, I might see a reason to buy one again. But what the mini really needs is a complete overhaul â€“ a new design and components that match what consumers expect in 2017. Oh, and a nice marketing push from Apple to help me feel better about parting with my hard earned cash. Maybe a 2017 Mac mini update is in the works and being kept remarkably well under wraps. Given that so many people prefer macOS and the Apple brand â€“ and that the Mac mini is, in terms of computers, the easiest way to get on board with these things â€“ it would make sense. Yet given the complete lack of rumours surrounding a Mac mini refresh, I fear for the future of this compact machine. It's a shame because, ultimately, it means that Apple is content with giving you a half-arsed user experience, undermining its great software by continuing to flog slow and outdated hardware. That's why, this Valentine's Day, I've fallen out of love with Apple. Come autumn, I hope Apple helps me open my heart again. WATCH: Laptop buying guide Do you agree with Michael? Share your thoughts in the comments below. I kept it until if could no longer process my yearly tax returns. But the new iMacs had gotten to be more expensive than I wanted to buy. My mom bought my first one as my birthday/Xmas present. A friend who has worked at Apple for years told me about the then, new Mac Mini. I wasted no time buying one. I am now on my second one, the last 2009 model. It may not be the fastest computer on the block, but it works for me most of the time, with some minor disruptions. I love me my Minis. So far, I have heard the 2010 Mini's are the end of the line of Minis. I refuse to accept that. I don't like laptops and their fragility. I also like that should anyone break in and want to steal my computer, they would likely walk right by my Mac mini, as most people don't even know what it is. As much as I like Apple products - I hate their pricing and I am on a budget for electronics, all which have a limited life. I don't know what I will do if Apple does not either continue the Mini, or come up with something equal or better at a lower price than their other computers. My hope is that Apple is not just content selling to smaller businesses, or those who have a lot more money to spend on electronics. Please, please, please. - either bring back my the MacMinis or, at least something equal or better at a fair market price for the budget minded! I want to stay loyal to Apple and I really don't like PC's. I had to use those at work for years and hated them. matt February 15, 2017, 4:42 am There was a recent article on the web that explained apples limited choices for mobile processors. You got to put part of the blame on intel. I'd love to see a Mac mini with a better video then intel , but intel would sue the crap out of you if you sold an i5 with nvidia graphics Edward Lock February 15, 2017, 6:30 am Why buy an overpriced Lemon like "MAC", when you can have a more capable lemon cream pie PC for less than 1/2 the price.WTF?...........puffy cuteness and esoteric purpleness, yea real useful. Bob Forsberg February 15, 2017, 7:35 am MacOS is my system of choice, but Apple's hardware is, as you say "ancient" by computer standards. Apple has transformed into a hand held device company, ignoring those of us using desktop systems. Since Apple lags in hardware manufacturing, they should license MacOS to run on superior and often refreshed, high-end PC hardware. We miss you Steve. itsallgonepearshaped February 15, 2017, 9:05 am I just bought myself an Intel NUC 6th Gen box. Smaller, lighter and faster than my old mac mini server. I'm moving away from MacOS back to windows due to the lack of investment and continually disappointing and constrained hardware. I will keep my Macbook pro for a couple more years as it's one a year old. Not sure about by my iMac 5k, it's a beautiful machine, but runs Windows under bootcamp(which I need for work) like a dysfunctional child. Alex Walsh February 15, 2017, 11:09 am Hackintosh a Gigabyte Brix? From a quick look Sierra is achievable. That's a proper Mac Mini :) Michael Passingham February 15, 2017, 12:24 pm Yeah, Apple is specific about the chips it wants. The most recent MacBook Pros used last-gen Skylake chips because the Kaby Lake chips apple uses (normally with Iris Graphics on board) weren't ready yet. But, all the same, I do think Apple could slap an SSD in, load it up with some more RAM and upgrade to a Skylake chip and lots of people would be happy. jheartney February 15, 2017, 1:20 pm Got tired of waiting for Apple to sell a reasonable mini-tower; I'm building a Hackintosh. (Macintosh owner since 1990; had more Macs than I can count. Apple's innovative DNA died with Steve, and now they're just a money factory.) Roger Randall February 15, 2017, 11:12 pm Um, there are three generations of Minis beyond the 2010 models. 2011, 2012 and the current (crippled) models. I have 4, one is a quad-core i7 that is pretty fast. You can still buy good used models (prices are going up though) and parts are still available. SCSZ February 16, 2017, 12:58 am I've seen that. But I am hoping Apple will change it's mind or make something better which won't cost to much. I don't want to spend money on a later model Mini and then find out a new one is coming out. I will wait 6 months or so, and see what happens. Image: apple music By Yvette Tan2017-02-14 09:52:26 UTC Apple Music's Beats 1 live radio station is now in Singapore, almost two years after the streaming music service was first launched in the country. Beats 1 Radio is a live 24/7 radio station, and was quietly launched on Tuesday in the city. SEE ALSO: Inside Apple Music's plan to take over the Indian market Singapore users â€” and those in countries which don't have access to the live Radio service â€” have until now only had access to Beats 1 On Demand, an aggregated version of the live broadcast, available as a recording. Apple's products are vastly popular in Singapore, with products like the iPhone usually launched here on the same day as the U.S. Singapore netizens have been calling for years for the online radio station to be launched. @AppleMusic why is Beats 1 radio still not available in Singapore? â€” Zin Ko Hlaing (@zinkohlaing) September 21, 2016 WTF. Beats 1 Radio is not available in Singapore. ðŸ˜¤ðŸ˜¤ thanks for nothing @AppleMusic ðŸ˜¨https://t.co/Ak0scj2jb6 â€” Sebastian Wieseler (@kickino) July 10, 2015 â€œWelcome to Beats 1, Worldwide, available in 100 countriesâ€¦â€ EXCEPT SINGAPORE LAH. Even Malaysia and Indonesia has Beats 1. Is it you, MDA? â€” mrbrown (@mrbrown) July 2, 2015 Beats 1 Radio, please come to #Singapore â€¦ â€” Anfernee (@anferneeck) July 4, 2015 Meanwhile, Beats 1 has been available in places across the region such as Hong Kong, Thailand and the Philippines since 2015.Â  The online show is aired live from Los Angeles, New York and London â€” with an anchor DJ producing the show in each city. It's here Image: apple music Currently, Beats 1 is still not available in the following countries: the Bahamas, Bahrain, Burkina-Faso, China, Egypt, Jordan, the Lebanon, Mozambique, Namibia, the UAE and Qatar. CLARIFICATION: Feb. 15, 2017, 2:53 p.m. SGT This article has been updated to distinguish the difference between Beats 1 live radio and the overall Beats 1 On Demand service. The ad gives us a glimpse into Appleâ€™s version of the popular Carpool Karaoke with James Corden which debuted on The Late Late Show. Apple first announced its plan for the show last year, with details slowly becoming available as time goes on. Todayâ€™s ad shows off the concept of rotating hosts which includeÂ John Legend, Will Smith, James Corden, Blake Shelton, and Shaquille Oâ€™Neal. Hereâ€™s the list of confirmed celebrities on board: Featuring James Corden, Will Smith, Billy Eichner, Metallica, Alicia Keys, John Legend, Ariana Grande, Seth MacFarlane, Chelsea Handler, Blake Shelton, Michael Strahan, John Cena, Shaquille Oâ€™Neal, and many more. The plot of the show seems to be the same as Cordenâ€™s version, with artists driving around singing popular tunes, talking to each other, and doing various activities. As previously noted, James Corden will not be hosting the show, but will be an executive producer for it. Apple plans on releasing 16 episodes, which will be at least 30 minutes in length. Corden will continue to do his version of theÂ series, but will be limited to one episode per month. Itâ€™s still unclear when Apple plans on releasing the new episodes, aside from â€œcoming soon to Apple Music.â€ Appleâ€™s description of the show reads: Based on the segment that has become a global, viral video sensation on The Late Late Show with James Corden, the new CARPOOL KARAOKE series features 16 celebrity pairings riding along in a car together as they sing tunes from their personal playlists and surprise fans who donâ€™t expect to see big stars belting out tunes one lane over.
